tensordb.file_handlers.ZarrStorage¶

class tensordb.file_handlers.ZarrStorage(name: str = 'data', chunks: Optional[Dict[str, int]] = None, synchronizer: Optional[Literal[process, thread]] = None, process_synchronizer_path: str = '', **kwargs)¶

Storage created for the Zarr files which implement the necessary methods to be used for TensorClient.

Internally it store a checksum for every chunk created by Zarr, this allow to speed up the backups and check the integrity of the data.

Parameters
name: str, default ‘data’

Name of the dataset, this is necessary if you want to work with Xarray DataArrays due that Xarray only support writes to Zarr files from datasets. Read the doc of to_dataset

chunks: Dict[str, int], default None

Define the chunks of the Zarr files, read the doc of the Xarray method to_zarr in the parameter ‘chunks’ for more details.

group: str, default None

read the doc of the Xarray method to_zarr in the parameter ‘group’ for more details.

synchronizer: {‘thread’, ‘process’}, default None

Depending on the option send it will create a zarr.sync.ThreadSynchronizer or a zarr.sync.ProcessSynchronizer for more info read the doc of Zarr synchronizer and the Xarray to_zarr method in the parameter ‘synchronizer’.

TODO:

  1. Add more examples to the documentation

  2. The next versions of zarr will add support for the modification dates of the chunks, that will simplify

    the code of backup, so It is a good idea modify the code after the modification being published

__init__(name: str = 'data', chunks: Optional[Dict[str, int]] = None, synchronizer: Optional[Literal[process, thread]] = None, process_synchronizer_path: str = '', **kwargs)¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

Methods

__init__([name, chunks, synchronizer, …])

Initialize self.

append(new_data[, compute, remote, …])

Append data at the end of a Zarr file (in case that the file does not exist it will call the store method), internally it calls the to_zarr method for every dimension of your data

backup([overwrite_backup])

Store the changes that you have done in your local path in the backup, it avoid overwrite unmodified chunks based in the checksum stored.

close(**kwargs)

Close the storage (Zarr does not need this but it will call the backup method automatically)

delete_file([only_local])

Delete the tensor

download_files(paths)

exist(on_local, **kwargs)

Indicate if the tensor exist or not

get_attrs([remote])

Read the metadata of a tensor stored using the set_attrs method

read([consolidated, remote])

Read the tensor stored in the Zarr file, internally it use open_zarr method.

remove_files(path_map, path[, recursive])

set_attrs([remote])

This is equivalent to use the .attrs of Xarray, so basically is used to add metadata to the tensors, these are writed in .zattrs file in json format

store(new_data[, compute, consolidated, …])

Store the data in the Zarr file, the dtype and all the details will depend of what you pass in the new_data parameter, internally this method calls the to_zarr method with a ‘w’ mode using that data.

transfer_files(receiver_path_map, …)

update(new_data[, remote, compute, …])

Replace data on an existing Zarr files based on the new_data, internally calls the to_zarr method using the region parameter, so it automatically create this region based on your new_data, in some cases it could even replace all the data in the file even if you only has two coords in your new_data this happend due that Xarray only allows to write in contigous blocks (region) (read carefully how the region parameter works in Xarray)

update_from_backup([force_update_from_backup])

Update the data in your local path using the data in the backup, it will only update the chunks that has a different checksum.

upload_files(paths)

upsert(new_data, **kwargs)

Calls the update and then the append method
